title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Mike wants to buy a new car. He has chosen a red car for $35000. To be able to pay this price, he needs to loan part of the money from the bank, at a rate of 15%. How much money in total will Mike need to pay for the car, if he has to take $20000 from the bank?

The interest on the loan is 20000 * 15/100 = $<<20000*15/100=3000>>3000.
So Mike has to pay 35000 + 3000 = $<<35000+3000=38000>>38000. Answer: \boxed{38000}.


Question: Mike wants to buy a new car. He has chosen a red car for $35000. To be able to pay this price, he needs to loan part of the money from the bank, at a rate of 15%. How much money in total will Mike need to pay for the car, if he has to take $20000 from the bank?

The loan from the bank is at a 15% rate, meaning Mike will have to pay $20000 * 15/100 = $<<20000*15/100=3000>>3000 interest.
The total price of the car will be $35000 + $3000 = $<<35000+3000=38000>>38000. Answer: \boxed{38000}.


Question: Mike wants to buy a new car. He has chosen a red car for $35000. To be able to pay this price, he needs to loan part of the money from the bank, at a rate of 15%. How much money in total will Mike need to pay for the car, if he has to take $20000 from the bank?

The bank charges Mike at an interest rate of 15%, so 15/100 * 20000 = $<<15/100*20000=3000>>3000.
So the car will cost Mike a total of 35000 + 3000 = $<<35000+3000=38000>>38000. Answer: \boxed{38000}.


Question: Mike wants to buy a new car. He has chosen a red car for $35000. To be able to pay this price, he needs to loan part of the money from the bank, at a rate of 15%. How much money in total will Mike need to pay for the car, if he has to take $20000 from the bank?

The bank will charge Mike an additional cost of 15/100 * $20000 = $<<15/100*20000=3000>>3000.
So for the car, he will have to pay a total cost of $35000 + $3000 = $<<35000+3000=38000>>38000. Answer: \boxed{38000}.


Question: Mike is saving up to buy a house.  He puts away 10% of his $150,000 a year salary.  He needs to save up 20% of the cost of a $450,000 house for a downpayment.  How long will it take?

Mike saves 150,000*.1=$<<150000*.1=15000>>15,000 per year
That means he needs to save 450,000*.2=$<<450000*.2=90000>>90,000
So he needs to save for 90,000/15,000=6 years. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: Mike wants to buy a new car. He has chosen a red car for $35000. To be able to pay this price, he needs to loan part of the money from the bank, at a rate of 15%. How much money in total will Mike need to pay for the car, if he has to take $20000 from the bank?
text:
The interest on the loan is calculated by multiplying the loan amount ($20000) by the interest rate (15%) which is equal to $20000 * 15/100 = $<<20000*15/100=3000>>3000.
Therefore, the total amount that Mike will need to pay for the car is the car price ($35000) plus the interest ($3000), which equals $35000 + $3000 = $<<35000+3000=38000>>38000. Answer: \boxed{38000}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Sandra has a box of apples that weighs 120 pounds.  She's going to use half the weight in apples to make applesauce.  The rest will be used to make apple pies.  She needs 4 pounds of apples per pie.  How many pies will she be able to make?

Sandra has 120/2 = <<120/2=60>>60 pounds of apples for making apple pies.
This will make 60/4 = <<60/4=15>>15 apple pies. Answer: \boxed{15}.


Question: Sandra has a box of apples that weighs 120 pounds.  She's going to use half the weight in apples to make applesauce.  The rest will be used to make apple pies.  She needs 4 pounds of apples per pie.  How many pies will she be able to make?

She's going to use half the weight of the apples which are 120/2 = <<120/2=60>>60 pounds of apples.
She can make 60/4 = <<60/4=15>>15 pies. Answer: \boxed{15}.


Question: Sandra has a box of apples that weighs 120 pounds.  She's going to use half the weight in apples to make applesauce.  The rest will be used to make apple pies.  She needs 4 pounds of apples per pie.  How many pies will she be able to make?

Half the weight of the apples is 120/2 = <<120/2=60>>60 pounds.
She'll be able to make 60/4 = <<60/4=15>>15 pies. Answer: \boxed{15}.


Question: Sandra has a box of apples that weighs 120 pounds.  She's going to use half the weight in apples to make applesauce.  The rest will be used to make apple pies.  She needs 4 pounds of apples per pie.  How many pies will she be able to make?

Half of 120 pounds of apples is 120/2=<<120/2=60>>60 pounds of apples
60 pounds of apples makes 60/4 = <<60/4=15>>15 apple pies. Answer: \boxed{15}.


Question: Sandra has a box of apples that weighs 120 pounds.  She's going to use half the weight in apples to make applesauce.  The rest will be used to make apple pies.  She needs 4 pounds of apples per pie.  How many pies will she be able to make?

She starts with 120 pounds of apples and will use half for applesauce and the other half for pies so she will use 120/2 = <<120/2=60>>60 pounds of apples
Each pie needs 4 pounds of apples and she has 60 pounds of apples so she will be able to make 60/4 = <<60/4=15>>15 apple pies. Answer: \boxed{15}.


Question: Sandra has a box of apples that weighs 120 pounds.  She's going to use half the weight in apples to make applesauce.  The rest will be used to make apple pies.  She needs 4 pounds of apples per pie.  How many pies will she be able to make?
text:
Sandra has 120 pounds of apples and she's going to use half the weight, which is 120/2 = <<120/2=60>>60 pounds of apples, to make applesauce.
The other half, also 60 pounds of apples, will be used to make apple pies.
Since she needs 4 pounds of apples per pie, she will be able to make 60/4 = <<60/4=15>>15 apple pies. Answer: \boxed{15}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Princeton had a gender reveal party and invited all of his fellow employees to celebrate with him. If the total number of guests were 60, and 2/3 were male guests, how many female guests attended the party?

If 2/3 of the guests were male, then 1/3 of the guests were female.
Since there were 60 guests in total, the number of female guests is 1/3*60 = <<1/3*60=20>>20. Answer: \boxed{20}.


Question: Princeton had a gender reveal party and invited all of his fellow employees to celebrate with him. If the total number of guests were 60, and 2/3 were male guests, how many female guests attended the party?

If 2/3 of the guests were male, then 1/3 of the guests were female.
The total number of guests who were female is 1/3*60 = <<1/3*60=20>>20. Answer: \boxed{20}.


Question: Princeton had a gender reveal party and invited all of his fellow employees to celebrate with him. If the total number of guests were 60, and 2/3 were male guests, how many female guests attended the party?

If the total number of guests were 60, and 2/3 were male guests, the number of male guests is 2/3*60 = <<2/3*60=40>>40
The number of female guests who attended the party is 60-40 = 20. Answer: \boxed{20}.


Question: Princeton had a gender reveal party and invited all of his fellow employees to celebrate with him. If the total number of guests were 60, and 2/3 were male guests, how many female guests attended the party?

The proportion of male guests is 2/3, which means that the proportion of female guests is 1 - 2/3 = 1/3.
There are 60 guests in total, so the number of female guests is 1/3 x 60 = <<1/3*60=20>>20. Answer: \boxed{20}.


Question: Princeton had a gender reveal party and invited all of his fellow employees to celebrate with him. If the total number of guests were 60, and 2/3 were male guests, how many female guests attended the party?

If there were 60 guests at Princeton's gender reveal party, and 2/3 were male guests, then (2/3)*60 = <<(2/3)*60=40>>40 guests were male.
The number of female guests who attended the party is 60 - 40 = <<60-40=20>>20. Answer: \boxed{20}.


Question: Princeton had a gender reveal party and invited all of his fellow employees to celebrate with him. If the total number of guests were 60, and 2/3 were male guests, how many female guests attended the party?
text:
If 2/3 of the guests were male, then the remaining 1/3 must be female. 
Since there were 60 guests in total, the number of female guests is 1/3 * 60 = 20. Answer: \boxed{20}.

title:

Examples:
    
Question: School coaches bought sports equipment. Coach A bought ten new basketballs for $29 each, while coach B bought 14 new baseballs for $2.50 each and a baseball bat for $18. How much more did coach A spend than coach B?

Coach A spent 10 x $29 = $<<10*29=290>>290.
Coach B spent 14 x $2.5 = $<<14*2.5=35>>35 for baseballs.
So, Coach B spent $35 + $18 = $<<35+18=53>>53.
Hence, Coach A spent $290 - $53 = $<<290-53=237>>237 more than Coach B. Answer: \boxed{237}.

title:

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: At the salad bar, Grandma put three mushrooms on her salad.  She also added twice as many cherry tomatoes as mushrooms, 4 times as many pickles as cherry tomatoes, and 4 times as many bacon bits as pickles.  If one third of the bacon bits were red, than how many red bacon bits did Grandma put on her salad?

Grandma put twice as many cherry tomatoes as mushrooms, or 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 cherry tomatoes.
Grandma added 4 times as many pickles as cherry tomatoes, or 4*6=<<4*6=24>>24 pickles.
She also put 4 times as many bacon bits as pickles, or 4*24= <<4*24=96>>96 bacon bits.
One third of the bacon bits were red, so 1/3*96 = <<1/3*96=32>>32 bacon bits were red. Answer: \boxed{32}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: For every one dozen flowers bought, a customer gets 2 free flowers. If Maria wants to buy 3 dozens flowers, how many pieces of flowers will she have in all?

If a customer buys 1 dozen flowers, they get 2 free flowers, meaning they get 12+2 = <<1*12+2=14>>14 flowers.
If Maria wants to buy 3 dozens of flowers, she will get 3*14 = <<3*14=42>>42 pieces of flowers. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: For every one dozen flowers bought, a customer gets 2 free flowers. If Maria wants to buy 3 dozens flowers, how many pieces of flowers will she have in all?

If Maria buys 3 dozen flowers, she will get 2 * 3 = <<3*2=6>>6 free flowers.
The total number of flowers Maria will have is 3 * 12 + 6 = <<3*12+6=42>>42 flowers. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: For every one dozen flowers bought, a customer gets 2 free flowers. If Maria wants to buy 3 dozens flowers, how many pieces of flowers will she have in all?

For every one dozen flowers, Maria gets 2 free flowers.
So if Maria buys 3 dozens of flowers, she will get 3 x 2 = <<3*2=6>>6 free flowers.
Thus, Maria will have a total of 3 x 12 + 6 = <<3*12+6=42>>42 pieces of flowers. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: For every one dozen flowers bought, a customer gets 2 free flowers. If Maria wants to buy 3 dozens flowers, how many pieces of flowers will she have in all?

For every one dozen flowers, there are 12 + 2 = <<12+2=14>>14 pieces of flowers.
Therefore, Maria will have 3 x 14 = <<3*14=42>>42 pieces of flowers. Answer: \boxed{42}.


Question: Maria's birthday is in 22 days. Her friend Lilly wants to buy her flowers so she saves $2 each day until Maria's birthday. If a flower costs $4, how many flowers can she buy?

Lilly will have saved a total of $2 x 22 = $<<2*22=44>>44.
Therefore, she can buy $44 / $4 = <<44/4=11>>11 flowers. Answer: \boxed{11}.


Question: For every one dozen flowers bought, a customer gets 2 free flowers. If Maria wants to buy 3 dozens flowers, how many pieces of flowers will she have in all?
text:
If Maria buys 3 dozen flowers, she will get 2 * 3 = <<3*2=6>>6 free flowers.
The total number of flowers Maria will have is 3 * 12 + 6 = <<3*12+6=42>>42 flowers. Answer: \boxed{42}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: There are 400 students in the senior class at East High School. 52% of the students play sports. Of the students that play sports, 12.5% play soccer. How many students play soccer?

52% of 400 students is (52/100)*400 = <<52/100*400=208>>208 students
12.5% of 208 students is (12.5/100)*208 = <<12.5/100*208=26>>26 students. Answer: \boxed{26}.


Question: There are 400 students in the senior class at East High School. 52% of the students play sports. Of the students that play sports, 12.5% play soccer. How many students play soccer?

The number of students that play sports is 400 x 52% = <<400*52*.01=208>>208 students.
The number of students that play soccer is 208 x 12.5% = <<208*12.5*.01=26>>26 students. Answer: \boxed{26}.


Question: There are 400 students in the senior class at East High School. 52% of the students play sports. Of the students that play sports, 12.5% play soccer. How many students play soccer?

The number of students that play sports is 400 students * 52% = <<400*52*.01=208>>208 students.
The number of students that play soccer is 208 students * 12.5% = <<208*12.5*.01=26>>26 students. Answer: \boxed{26}.


Question: There are 400 students in the senior class at East High School. 52% of the students play sports. Of the students that play sports, 12.5% play soccer. How many students play soccer?

Out of the 400 students, 52/100 x 400 = <<52/100*400=208>>208 play sports.
Of the 208 students that play sports, 12.5/100 x 208 = <<12.5/100*208=26>>26 play soccer. Answer: \boxed{26}.


Question: There are 400 students in the senior class at East High School. 52% of the students play sports. Of the students that play sports, 12.5% play soccer. How many students play soccer?

There are 400 x 52/100 = <<400*52/100=208>>208 students who play sports.
Out of these 208, 208 x 12.5/100= <<208*12.5/100=26>>26 students play soccer. Answer: \boxed{26}.


Question: There are 400 students in the senior class at East High School. 52% of the students play sports. Of the students that play sports, 12.5% play soccer. How many students play soccer?
text:
The number of students that play sports is 400 students * 52% = 208 students.
The number of students that play soccer is 208 students * 12.5% = 26 students. Answer: \boxed{26}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Anais has 30 more toys than Kamari. There are 160 toys altogether. How many toys are there in Kamari's box?

Let the number of toys Kamari has be x
Anais has 30 + x.
x + (x + 30) = 160
2x + 30 = 160
2x = 160 - 30
2x = 130
x = 130/2
x = <<65=65>>65
Kamari has <<65=65>>65 toys. Answer: \boxed{65}.


Question: Anais has 30 more toys than Kamari. There are 160 toys altogether. How many toys are there in Kamari's box?

Let 'x' be the number of toys in Kamari's box.
Anais has x+30 toys.
x + x+ 30 = 160.
2x = 130.
x = <<65=65>>65 toys. Answer: \boxed{65}.


Question: Anais has 30 more toys than Kamari. There are 160 toys altogether. How many toys are there in Kamari's box?

Let's say the number of toys Kamari has is x.
Anais has x+30 toys.
The total number of toys is x+x+30 = 160.
Combining like terms, we get 2x=160-30
Combining like terms, we get 2x=130
Dividing both sides by 2, we get x=65 toys. Answer: \boxed{65}.


Question: Anais has 30 more toys than Kamari. There are 160 toys altogether. How many toys are there in Kamari's box?

Let the number of toys in Kamari's box be x.
Anais has x + 30 toys.
The total number of toys is x + x + 30 = 160.
2x + 30 = 160
2x = 160 - 30
2x = 130
x = 130/2
x = <<65=65>>65
There are 65 toys in Kamari's box. Answer: \boxed{65}.


Question: Anais has 30 more toys than Kamari. There are 160 toys altogether. How many toys are there in Kamari's box?

Let x be the number of toys in Kamari's box.
Anais has x + 30 toys.
Thus, x + x + 30 = 160.
Thus, 2x = 160 - 30 = <<160-30=130>>130.
Thus, Kamari has x = 130 / 2 = <<130/2=65>>65 toys in her box. Answer: \boxed{65}.


Question: Anais has 30 more toys than Kamari. There are 160 toys altogether. How many toys are there in Kamari's box?
text:
Let the number of toys in Kamari's box be x.
Anais has x + 30 toys.
The total number of toys is x + (x + 30) = 160.
Combining like terms, we get 2x + 30 = 160.
Subtracting 30 from both sides, we get 2x = 160 - 30.
Simplifying, we get 2x = 130.
Dividing both sides by 2, we get x = 130/2.
Therefore, Kamari has x = 65 toys in her box. Answer: \boxed{65}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Mark's basketball team scores 25 2 pointers, 8 3 pointers and 10 free throws.  Their opponents score double the 2 pointers but half the 3 pointers and free throws.  What's the total number of points scored by both teams added together?

A 2 pointer is worth 2 points and Mark's basketball team scores 25 of them so he scores 2*25 = <<2*25=50>>50 points
A 3 pointer is worth 3 points and Mark's basketball team scores 8 of them so he scores 3*8 = <<3*8=24>>24 points
Mark's team scores 10 free throws and that's one point each so he scores 10*1 = <<10*1=10>>10 points
All total Mark's basketball team scores 50 2-pointers, 24 3-pointers and 10 free throws for 50+24+10 = <<50+24+10=84>>84 points
Mark's opponents score double the 2 pointers Mark's team scored so they score 2*50 = <<2*50=100>>100 points
Mark's opponents scored half the 3 pointers Mark's team did so they scored 24/2 = <<24/2=12>>12 points
Mark's opponents scored half the free throws Mark's team did so they scored 10/2 = <<10/2=5>>5 points
All total, Mark's opponents scored 100 2-pointers, 12 3-pointers and 5 free throws for a total of 100+12+5 = <<100+12+5=117>>117 points
Together, both teams scored 84+117 = <<84+117=201>>201 points. Answer: \boxed{201}.


Question: Mark's basketball team scores 25 2 pointers, 8 3 pointers and 10 free throws.  Their opponents score double the 2 pointers but half the 3 pointers and free throws.  What's the total number of points scored by both teams added together?

Mark's team scores 25 2 pointers which are each worth 2 points for a total of 25*2 = <<25*2=50>>50 points
Marks team scores 8 3 pointers which are each worth 3 points and their opponents score double that many 2 pointers so they score 8*3 = <<8*3=24>>24 points
Mark's team scores 10 free throws which are each worth 1 point for a total of 10*1 = <<10*1=10>>10 points
Together they score 50+24+10 = <<50+24+10=84>>84 points
Their opponents score double the 2 pointers so they score 2*50 = <<2*50=100>>100 points
Their opponents score half the 3 pointers so they score 3*.5*8 = <<3*.5*8=12>>12 points
Their opponents score half the free throws so they score .5*10 = <<10*.5=5>>5 points
Together both teams score 84+100+12+5 = <<84+100+12+5=201>>201 points. Answer: \boxed{201}.


Question: Mark's basketball team scores 25 2 pointers, 8 3 pointers and 10 free throws.  Their opponents score double the 2 pointers but half the 3 pointers and free throws.  What's the total number of points scored by both teams added together?

Mark's team scores 25 2 pointers, so that means they score 25*2=<<25*2=50>>50 points
His team also scores 8 3 pointers, so that means they score 8*3= <<8*3=24>>24 points
And his team scores 10 free throws, so that means they score 10*1= 10 points
All together, that means his team scores 50+24+10= <<50+24+10=84>>84 points
Their opponents score double the number of 2 pointers, so that means they scored 2*50= <<2*50=100>>100 points
Their opponents score half the number of 3 pointers, so that means they score 3*8/2=12 points
Their opponents score half the number of free throws, so that means they score 10/2=<<10/2=5>>5 points
All together, their opponents scored 100+12+5= <<100+12+5=117>>117 points
Adding both of their scores together, means in total they scored 84+117=<<84+117=201>>201 points. Answer: \boxed{201}.


Question: In a math test, Mark scored twice as much as the least score. If the highest score is 98 and the range of the scores is 75, what was Mark's score?

Let's say the least score is x.
Mark's score is 2x.
The range is the difference between the highest and the least score: 98 - x = 75.
So x = 98 - 75, which is x = <<98-75=23>>23.
Mark's score is 2 * 23 = <<2*23=46>>46. Answer: \boxed{46}.


Question: In a math test, Mark scored twice as much as the least score. If the highest score is 98 and the range of the scores is 75, what was Mark's score?

Let x be the least score.
Mark scored 2x.
The range of the scores is the difference between the highest and the least score, so 75 = 98 - x
Thus, the least score is 98 - 75 = <<98-75=23>>23.
So, Mark scored 2 * <<23*2=46>>46. Answer: \boxed{46}.


Question: Mark's basketball team scores 25 2 pointers, 8 3 pointers and 10 free throws.  Their opponents score double the 2 pointers but half the 3 pointers and free throws.  What's the total number of points scored by both teams added together?
text:
First, let's calculate Mark's team's score. They score 25 2-pointers, which are worth 2 points each, so that is 25 * 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 points. They also score 8 3-pointers, which are worth 3 points each, so that is 8 * 3 = <<8*3=24>>24 points. Finally, they score 10 free throws, which are worth 1 point each, so that is 10 * 1 = <<10*1=10>>10 points. In total, Mark's team scores 50 + 24 + 10 = <<50+24+10=84>>84 points.

Now let's calculate the opponent's team's score. They score double the number of 2-pointers Mark's team scored, so that is 2 * 50 = <<2*50=100>>100 points. They score half the number of 3-pointers Mark's team scored, so that is 3 * 0.5 * 8 = <<3*0.5*8=12>>12 points. They also score half the number of free throws Mark's team scored, so that is 0.5 * 10 = <<0.5*10=5>>5 points. In total, the opponent's team scores 100 + 12 + 5 = <<100+12+5=117>>117 points.

To find the total number of points scored by both teams added together, we simply add Mark's team's score and the opponent's team's score: 84 + 117 = <<84+117=201>>201 points. Answer: \boxed{201}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A Whatsapp group has members sending messages every day sharing about how each one's day was. Last week, 300 messages were sent by the members on Monday, 200 messages on Tuesday, 300 more messages on Wednesday than the previous day, and two times as many messages on Thursday as there were on Wednesday. Calculate the number of messages sent in the Whatsapp group after the four days.

If 300 messages were sent on Monday, and 200 messages on Tuesday, the total for the two days is 300+200 = <<300+200=500>>500 messages.
The total number of messages sent on Wednesday is 300 more messages than Tuesday = 300+200 = <<300+200=500>>500 messages.
The total number of messages sent in the group on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday is 500+500 = <<500+500=1000>>1000 messages.
The number of messages sent on Thursday is 2 times the number sent on Wednesday which is 2*500 = <<2*500=1000>>1000 messages.
After the four days, the total number of messages sent is 1000+1000 = <<1000+1000=2000>>2000 messages. Answer: \boxed{2000}.


Question: A Whatsapp group has members sending messages every day sharing about how each one's day was. Last week, 300 messages were sent by the members on Monday, 200 messages on Tuesday, 300 more messages on Wednesday than the previous day, and two times as many messages on Thursday as there were on Wednesday. Calculate the number of messages sent in the Whatsapp group after the four days.

The number of messages on Wednesday was 300+200 = <<300+200=500>>500 messages
On Thursday, there were two times as many messages as on Wednesday, a total of 2*500 = <<2*500=1000>>1000 messages.
The total number of messages sent in the Whatsapp group after the four days is 300+200+500+1000 = <<300+200+500+1000=2000>>2000. Answer: \boxed{2000}.


Question: After violating the group's policies, 20 members of a Facebook group were removed by the group's admin. If each member posted 50 messages per day in the group and the number of members in the group was 150 before the admin removed some, calculate the total number of messages the remaining members would send in a week.

If the number of members in the group was 150 before some members were removed, there were 150-20 = <<150-20=130>>130 members.
If 20 members were removed from the group, the total number of members remaining in the group is 130.
The number of messages sent by each group member in a day is 50.
The total number of messages sent in the group in a day is 50*130 = <<50*130=6500>>6500 messages.
In a week, with 7 days, the number of messages sent in the group is 6500*7 = <<6500*7=45500>>45500. Answer: \boxed{45500}.


Question: After violating the group's policies, 20 members of a Facebook group were removed by the group's admin. If each member posted 50 messages per day in the group and the number of members in the group was 150 before the admin removed some, calculate the total number of messages the remaining members would send in a week.

If the number of members in the group before some were removed by the admin was 150, and 20 were removed, the number of members remaining is 150-20 = <<150-20=130>>130
Since each member posted 50 messages per day, over a week, with 7 days, each member would send 7*50 = <<7*50=350>>350 messages in a week.
If there are 130 members remaining in the group, the total number of messages they would send in a week is 130*350 = <<130*350=45500>>45500. Answer: \boxed{45500}.


Question: After violating the group's policies, 20 members of a Facebook group were removed by the group's admin. If each member posted 50 messages per day in the group and the number of members in the group was 150 before the admin removed some, calculate the total number of messages the remaining members would send in a week.

If there were 150 members in the group before the admin removed some, and each member in the group posted 50 messages per day, the total number of messages sent by each member in a day is 150 members* 50 messages/member = <<150*50=7500>>7500 messages.
Since there are 7 days in a week, all the members would have posted a total of 7500 messages/day * 7days/week = <<7500*7=52500>>52500 messages in a week if they were all present.
If 20 members of the group were removed by the admin, the remaining members total is 150 members - 20 members = <<150-20=130>>130 members.
Since each member posts 50 messages per day, the total number of messages sent by the remaining members is 50 messages/member * 130 members = <<50*130=6500>>6500 messages in a day.
In a week, the number of messages sent by the remaining members is 6500 messages/day * 7days/week = <<6500*7=45500>>45500 messages. Answer: \boxed{45500}.


Question: A Whatsapp group has members sending messages every day sharing about how each one's day was. Last week, 300 messages were sent by the members on Monday, 200 messages on Tuesday, 300 more messages on Wednesday than the previous day, and two times as many messages on Thursday as there were on Wednesday. Calculate the number of messages sent in the Whatsapp group after the four days.
text:
If 300 messages were sent on Monday, and 200 messages on Tuesday, the total for the two days is 300+200 = <<300+200=500>>500 messages.
The total number of messages sent on Wednesday is 300 more messages than Tuesday = 300+200 = <<300+200=500>>500 messages.
The total number of messages sent in the group on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday is 500+500 = <<500+500=1000>>1000 messages.
The number of messages sent on Thursday is 2 times the number sent on Wednesday which is 2*500 = <<2*500=1000>>1000 messages.
After the four days, the total number of messages sent is 1000+1000 = <<1000+1000=2000>>2000 messages. Answer: \boxed{2000}.
